pros: People on the team are nice and friendly Good work life balance

pros: Working Remote and Health Benefits.
cons:
Where do I start?

From Poor Leadership, Micromanagement, and deplorable software platforms utilizes where do I begin? 

I had to write a review because I've tolerated so much from this company for over two years. 

When I first began my role at SWHR, I was elated because I was veering away from a call center environment... however that has changed drastically. Workflow changes occur every week where the employees are unable to adjust to a steady workflow process. We have now transitioned to a call center environment which is pointless since my department only processes referrals and sends to the specialist. Taking calls only hinders the employee from completing goals/metrics that are changed every week (even though leadership states that no quotas have been put in place) 

Lack of Successful training occurred when knew processes are implemented which creates confusion and unwarranted punitive treatment when the mistakes could be alleviated with the proper communication and training set forth. 

Leadership qualifications are based off of nepotism not qualifications, skill and experience. More duties are added when pay isn't adequate to our non-applicable job descriptions. 

Lastly, Lack of assistance from Leadership when problems arise.

review_title: SWHR ? More like DLHR(Direction-Less Health Resources)
pros:
Decent pay, benefits
Some awesome people to work with
cons:
SWHR is a middle-man, they basically serve up contracts to insurance companies that they TRY to fulfill but at the expense of their employees without careful planning of the resources needed. My view is that this organization has been built to serve the parents which are not bad places to work.

One of the biggest issues is the constant change in direction which can be attributed to extremely high turn-over in leadership (you can google this with the constant updates of new appointments) and the battle to win contracts without the bandwidth to manage them. I don't think they really care about patients that don't yield revenues.

Another issue is the politics. Leadership is like a good 'ol boys club and yes they preach diversity but just look at the mix. 

The leadership is also very poor ; they will literally lie on team meeting huddles ; tell you everything is good and 2 weeks later something drastic happens in the name of "change for better" numbers and targets change overnight and then the blame game starts followed by chopping blocks.

Recent promotions have put people in leadership positions but they are neither leaders nor managers - it really is sad because there is so much potential.

COVID vaccines were mandated even for people with medical conditions with ultimatums given that if not completed would automatically mean a termination and this is a healthcare organization???

I could go on and on but these are significant issues that have tarnished the image of SWHR.

pros:
Some really talented and intelligent people
Good vision
cons:
Micromanagement
Office politics
Favoritism
So 70s



To give some context, this was my first foyer into a "progressive" healthcare company. I come from literally every industry vertical and this has by far been the worst experience and it was bad enough to review - haven't done this for any of my previous employers. I will say, it teaches you ALOT so read on, be your own judge.

My experience started ok but went down the drain due to a terrible manager, so this might be limited to the group.

Micromanagement : can't email outside my division without copying the boss on EVERYTHING!

Belittling : There were meetings where my team was literally threatened/belittled by other directors that we won't have a job if we do not meet contractual obligations that span the entire organization. If you want to succeed here, just be a "Yes-Man" and don't stand up to the bullys.

Political Awareness : I literally had people asking indirectly and directly my political affiliations and it wasn't once. It was really disgusting and cheap and my answers were neutral.

It is easier to let an entire team go [oh did I mention, the team that went out in covid (still not sure if they was fully legal since we were "care-coordinators" not "care givers"), without vaccinations, full PPE, got trained on using eye cameras, pulled reporting to meet contractual obligations, improved workflows for other teams] than let go of one white racist team member: HR does nothing and their process was painful from a documentation perspective. So yeah..... If you want to be used and abused, this is the perfect spot.

To sum it up, there is no substance to the company, it's an empty healthcare-capitalizing machine. There are some really great people to work with that are friendly and know their respective domains but they're also stuck with their hands tied.

review_title: A visionary company with endless potential
pros: 1) Since we're a new company, you have the opportunity to help shape the culture and the business; 2) The collective experience of our employees across the company is amazing; 3) We are set up for success, for too many reasons to list here; 4) For two years straight, we've ranked No. 1 among similar organizations nationwide.
cons: 1) We're new, so there's a lack of name recognition; lots of opportunity here; 2) Employees are located in multiples locations across DFW; we should all be in one building within 1-2 years, I hear.

pros: I really like that the company quickly switched from working on campus to working from home due to the corona virus and the company president is not in any hurry to have us go back to the office. I think we have the best health care insurance! Training was good and you are not left to sink or swim. The training team is always there to answer any question you may have to enable you do your job.
cons: It is a production based job so you really have to work hard to meet all set goals
